revision.text:
{{About|the film|the video game|Shrek Forever After (video game)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = Shrek Forever After | image = Shrek forever after ver8.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | border = yes | director = [[Mike Mitchell (director)|Mike Mitchell]] | producer = {{plainlist| * [[Gina Shay]] * [[Teresa Cheng]] }} | writer = {{plainlist| * [[Josh Klausner]] * [[Darren Lemke]] }} | based on = {{based on|''[[Shrek!]]''|[[William Steig]]}} | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Mike Myers]] * [[Eddie Murphy]] * [[Cameron Diaz]] * [[Antonio Banderas]] * [[Julie Andrews]] * [[John Cleese]] * [[Walt Dohrn]] }} | music = [[Harry Gregson-Williams]] | editing = [[Nick Fletcher]] | studio = [[DreamWorks Animation]]{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/members//catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=66591|title=Shrek Forever After|work=[[AFI Catalog of Feature Films]]|accessdate=June 12, 2017}} | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2010|4|21|[[Tribeca Film Festival]]|2010|5|21|United States}} | country = United States | language = English | runtime = 93 minutes | budget = $135{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2353030520100523|title=UPDATE 1-'Shrek' sequel underperforms at box office|last=Goodman|first=Dean|work=[[Reuters]]|publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]]|date=May 23, 2010|accessdate=August 16, 2010|quote="Shrek Forever After," with the voice cast including Michael Myers, Antonio Banderas, Eddie Murphy, Cameron Diaz, cost about $135 million to make. Worldwide marketing costs will be about $165 million, Globe said.}}{{cite news|last1=DiOrio|first1=Carl|title='Shrek' underwhelms but tops boxoffice|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/shrek-underwhelms-tops-boxoffice-23907|accessdate=December 23, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=May 23, 2010|quote=Produced for an estimated $135 million,...}}–$165{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=shrek4.htm|title=Shrek Forever After (2010)|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]]|accessdate=August 22, 2010}} million | gross = $752.6 million }} '''''Shrek Forever After''''' (previously promoted as '''''Shrek: The Final Chapter'''''{{cite web|last1=Sciretta|first1=Peter|title=Has Shrek Forever After Been Renamed Shrek: The Final Chapter?|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/has-shrek-forever-after-been-renamed-shrek-the-final-chapter/|website=/Film|accessdate=June 22, 2017}}) is a 2010 American [[computer animation|computer-animated]], [[comedy film]] by [[DreamWorks Animation]]. It is the fourth installment in the [[Shrek (franchise)|''Shrek'' film franchise]] and the sequel to ''[[Shrek the Third]]'' (2007). The film was directed by [[Mike Mitchell (director)|Mike Mitchell]] from a script by [[Josh Klausner]] and [[Darren Lemke]], and stars [[Mike Myers]], [[Eddie Murphy]], [[Cameron Diaz]], [[Antonio Banderas]], [[Julie Andrews]], and [[John Cleese]] reprising their previous roles, with [[Walt Dohrn]] introduced in the role of [[Rumpelstiltskin]]. The plot follows Shrek struggling as a family man with no privacy, who yearns for the days when he was once feared. He is tricked by Rumpelstiltskin into signing a contract that leads to disastrous consequences. The film premiered at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]] on April 21, 2010. It was theatrically released in the [[United States]] by [[Paramount Pictures]] on May 21, 2010, in [[3D film|3D]] and [[IMAX#IMAX 3D|IMAX 3D]] formats. The film debuted as the top-grossing film at the box office, a position it held for three consecutive weeks in the United States and Canada, grossing a worldwide total of $752 million and becoming the [[2010 in film|fifth-highest-grossing film of 2010]]. In addition, ''Shrek Forever After'' became DreamWorks Animation's second-highest-grossing film at the foreign box office.{{cite web|last=Heath|first=Paul|url=http://www.thehollywoodnews.com/2010/09/07/shrek-forever-after-becomes-dreamworks-animations-biggest-release/|title=Shrek Forever After becomes Dreamworks Animation's biggest release|publisher=The Hollywood News|date=September 7, 2010}} Although originally marketed as the final installment in the film franchise, a [[Shrek (franchise)|fifth ''Shrek'' film]] has unofficially been reported to be in production with speculation it could be released as early as 2019.{{cite web|last1=O'Connell|first1=Sean|title=When Shrek 5 Could Hit Theaters, According To Eddie Murphy|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/news/1556529/when-shrek-5-could-hit-theaters-according-to-eddie-murphy|publisher=Cinemablend|accessdate=September 17, 2016|date=September 16, 2016}} ==Plot== In a flashback, King Harold and Queen Lillian are about to sign the kingdom of Far Far Away over to Rumpelstiltskin, in exchange for lifting their daughter's curse. The deal is abruptly cancelled at the last second when a knight informs the King and Queen that [[Princess Fiona]] has been rescued by [[Shrek (character)|Shrek]]. An angry Rumpelstiltskin laments his loss and wishes that Shrek was never born. In the present time, Shrek has grown steadily weary of being a family man and celebrity among the local villagers, leading him to wish for when he felt like a "real [[ogre]]" again. When he takes his family to Far Far Away to celebrate his children's first birthday, a series of mishaps further injure his ego, causing him to lose his temper and walk out in anger. Shrek encounters Rumpelstiltskin, who seizes his chance, having observed Shrek's angry outburst. He follows Shrek and arranges for him to appear to save his life. He gives Shrek a day to live like a real ogre, in exchange for a day from his childhood that he would not remember being erased to "thank" him. Shrek signs the contract and appears in an [[Parallel universes in fiction|alternate reality]] where the events starting from [[Shrek|Fiona's rescue]] are irrelevant. Now feared by villagers, he takes the opportunity to cause some lighthearted mischief until he finds "WANTED" posters for Fiona and his home deserted and desolate. He is kidnapped by [[Witchcraft|witches]] and taken to Rumpel, now the King of Far Far Away, which has become derelict and run down. Upon inquiry, Rumpel reveals that he took away the day Shrek was born. Therefore, Shrek never saved Fiona or met [[Donkey (Shrek)|Donkey]], and consequently Rumpel was able to trick King Harold and Queen Lillian into signing their kingdom over to him, making them both disappear. When the day ends, Shrek will disappear as well as he was never born in this timeline. Shrek escapes Rumpel's castle with Donkey. Initially terrified of Shrek, Donkey decides to trust him after seeing Shrek cry over his erased history, something he had never seen an ogre do before. After Shrek explains the situation, Donkey helps him find a hidden exit clause: the contract can be nullified by "true love's kiss". They soon encounter an army of ogres who are resisting Rumpel. The ogres are led by a still-cursed Fiona who, after escaping from the tower where she was held captive, keeps the retired and overweight [[Puss in Boots (Shrek)|Puss in Boots]] as a pet. Shrek does everything he can to gain Fiona's love, but she is too busy preparing an ambush on Rumpel. She is also bitterly cynical and disillusioned about the power of true love and throws herself into planning Rumpel's capture. While sparring with her, Fiona begins to like Shrek, but stops short of kissing him. Puss encourages him to continue pursuing Fiona. During the ambush, the ogres are captured by the [[Pied Piper of Hamelin|Pied Piper]], though Shrek and Fiona escape with the intervention of Puss and Donkey. Shrek insists Fiona kiss him, saying it will fix everything; however, because in this altered timeline Fiona does not truly love him, the kiss does not work. When he hears that Rumpel is offering a wish to the one who brings him Shrek, Shrek turns himself in and uses the wish to free the other ogres. Afterwards, Rumpel reveals a captured Fiona whom he is going to feed to Dragon along with Shrek. Donkey leads the Ogre army to storm the castle, battle the witches, and capture Rumpel, while Shrek and Fiona trap Dragon. As the sun rises, Shrek begins to fade from existence, but Fiona, having fallen in love with him, kisses Shrek just before he disappears, restoring Shrek to his world just before he lashed out at the party. Shrek embraces his friends and family with a newfound appreciation for everything he has. ==Cast== {{multiple image|perrow = 2/3|total_width=320 | image1 = Mike Myers David Shankbone 2010 NYC.jpg|width1=930|height1=1203 | image2 = Eddie Murphy Tribeca Shankbone 2010 NYC (2).jpg|width2=730|height2=1024 | image3 = Cameron Diaz by David Shankbone.jpg |width3=1025|height3=1321 | image4 = Antonio Banderas.jpg|width4=1227|height4=1588 | image5 = Walt Dohrn Shankbone 2010 NYC.jpg|width5=1143|height5=1473 | footer = [[Mike Myers]], [[Eddie Murphy]], [[Cameron Diaz]],
[[Antonio Banderas]] and [[Walt Dohrn]] at the premiere of
the film at the 2010 [[Tribeca Film Festival]]. | footer_align = center }} {{Main|List of Shrek characters}} * [[Mike Myers]] as [[Shrek (character)|Shrek]] * [[Eddie Murphy]] as [[Donkey (Shrek)|Donkey]] * [[Cameron Diaz]] as [[Princess Fiona]] * [[Antonio Banderas]] as [[Puss in Boots (Shrek)|Puss in Boots]] * [[Julie Andrews]] as [[List of Shrek characters#Queen Lillian|Queen Lillian]] * [[John Cleese]] as [[List of Shrek characters#King Harold|King Harold]] * [[Walt Dohrn]] as [[List of Shrek characters#Rumpelstiltskin|Rumpelstiltskin]] * [[Jon Hamm]] as Brogan the Ogre * [[Jane Lynch]] as Gretched the Ogre * [[Craig Robinson (actor)|Craig Robinson]] as Cookie the Ogre * [[Lake Bell]] as Patrol Witch, Wagon Witch No. 2 * [[Kathy Griffin]] as Dancing Witch and Wagon Witch No. 1 * [[Mary Kay Place]] as Guard Witch * [[Kristen Schaal]] as Pumpkin Witch, Palace Witch * [[Conrad Vernon]] as [[Gingerbread Man (Shrek)|Gingerbread Man]] * [[Aron Warner]] as [[List of Shrek characters#Big Bad Wolf|Wolf]] * [[Christopher Knights]] as [[List of Shrek characters#Three Blind Mice|Blind Mice]] * [[Cody Cameron]] as [[List of Shrek characters#Pinocchio|Pinocchio]], [[List of Shrek characters#Three Little Pigs|Three Pigs]] * [[Chris Miller (animator)|Chris Miller]] as Magic Mirror, [[List of Shrek characters#Mr. Geppetto|Geppetto]] * [[Meredith Vieira]] as Broomsy Witch * [[Jeremy Steig]] as [[Pied Piper of Hamelin|Pied Piper]] * [[Larry King]] as [[List of Shrek characters#Doris the ugly stepsister|Doris the Ugly Stepsister]] * [[Regis Philbin]] as [[Mabel]] the Ugly Stepsister * [[Mike Mitchell (director)|Mike Mitchell]] as Witch Guard No. 2 and Butter Pants * [[Ryan Seacrest]] as Father of Butter Pants ==Production== Following the success of ''[[Shrek 2]]'', a third and fourth ''Shrek'' film, along with plans for a fifth and final film, were announced in May 2004 by Jeffrey Katzenberg.{{cite web | url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/516/516377p1.html | title=More Shrek | publisher=[[IGN]] | date=May 17, 2004 | accessdate=March 9, 2012 | author=Linder, Brian}} In October 2006, [[DreamWorks Animation]] revealed that the fourth film would be released in 2010.{{cite web|title=Shrek 4 Coming to Theaters in 2010|url=http://comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=17293|publisher=ComingSoon.net|accessdate=May 14, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061125050334/http://comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=17293|archivedate=November 25, 2006|date=November 1, 2006}} In October 2007, Katzenberg announced a title for the fourth film, ''Shrek Goes Fourth'',{{cite news|title=DreamWorks Animation Announces Fall 2010 Title|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=38922|accessdate=March 10, 2012|newspaper=ComingSoon.net|date=October 31, 2007}} explaining that "Shrek goes out into the world, forth!"{{cite news|last=Bartyzel|first=Monika|title=Katzenberg Talks 'Shrek Goes Fourth' and 'Bee Movie 2'|url=http://blog.moviefone.com/2007/11/20/katzenberg-talks-shrek-goes-fourth-and-bee-movie-2/|accessdate=March 10, 2012|newspaper=CineMatical|date=November 20, 2007|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120711061516/http://blog.moviefone.com/2007/11/20/katzenberg-talks-shrek-goes-fourth-and-bee-movie-2/#|archive-date=July 11, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} In May 2009, however, DreamWorks Animation retitled the film to ''Shrek Forever After'',{{cite news|title=DreamWorks Animation Announces Plans to Release Five Feature Films Every Two Years|url=http://ir.dreamworksanimation.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=540593|accessdate=March 8, 2012|newspaper=DreamWorks Animation|date=May 28, 2009|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120527053108/http://ir.dreamworksanimation.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=540593|archive-date=May 27, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} indicating that it would be the last in the ''Shrek'' series.{{Citation needed|reason=reference doesn't mention anything about it being the last film|date=January 2017}} In November 2009, [[Bill Damaschke]], head of creative production at DreamWorks Animation, confirmed with "All that was loved about Shrek in the [[Shrek|first film]] is brought to the final film."{{cite news|last=Wloszczyna|first=Susan|title=First look: 'Shrek Forever After': Fourth, final film is first in 3-D|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2009-11-24-shrek-forever-after_N.htm|accessdate=February 23, 2012|newspaper=USA Today|date=November 26, 2009}} [[Tim Sullivan (British filmmaker)|Tim Sullivan]] was hired to write the script in March 2005,{{cite news|date= March 6, 2005|url= http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117918987|archive-url= https://archive.is/20130205202103/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117918987|dead-url= yes|archive-date= February 5, 2013|title= DreamWorks plans 'Shrek 4'|publisher= Variety|accessdate= August 29, 2010}} but was later replaced by [[Darren Lemke]] and [[Josh Klausner]]. Klausner, about the script's evolution, said, "When I first came onto the project, it wasn't supposed to be the final chapter—there were originally going to be 5 ''Shrek'' movies. Then, about a year into the development, Jeffrey Katzenberg decided that the story that we'd come up with was the right way for Shrek's journey to end, which was incredibly flattering."{{cite news|last=Eckerling|first=Debra|title=We Asked ... Josh Klausner and Darren Lemke, "Shrek Forever After"|url=http://www.storylink.com/article/346|accessdate=March 10, 2012|newspaper=Storylink|date=May 18, 2010}} In May 2007, shortly before the release of the third film, it was announced [[Mike Mitchell (director)|Mike Mitchell]] would be on board to direct the new installment.{{cite news|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=20254 |title=Mike Mitchell to Direct Shrek 4 |publisher=Coming Soon.net |date=May 7, 2007 |accessdate=January 13, 2009}} Much of the film was written and recorded in [[New York City]].{{cite web | url=http://lineboil.com/interview-with-shrek-forever-after-director-mike-mitchell/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102192710/http://lineboil.com/interview-with-shrek-forever-after-director-mike-mitchell/ | dead-url=yes | archive-date=January 2, 2014 | title=Interview with Shrek Forever After Director Mike Mitchell | publisher=Lineboil | date=April 22, 2010 | accessdate=January 8, 2012 | author=Aaron }} ==Soundtrack== {{Main|List of songs featured in Shrek#Shrek Forever After|l1=List of songs featured in Shrek Forever After}} Similar to most of the other ''Shrek'' films, the film's original score was composed by [[United Kingdom|British]] composer [[Harry Gregson-Williams]]. ==Release== ''Shrek Forever After'' premiered at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]] on April 21, 2010.{{cite news|last=McCracken|first=Kristin|title=Shrek Forever After to Open TFF 2010|url=http://www.tribecafilm.com/festival/news-views/Shrek_Forever_After_to_Open_TFF_2010.html|accessdate=May 24, 2012|newspaper=Tribeca Film Festival|date=March 1, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526072738/http://www.tribecafilm.com/festival/news-views/Shrek_Forever_After_to_Open_TFF_2010.html|archivedate=May 26, 2012|df=mdy-all}} It was publicly released on May 20, 2010, in Russia, while the American release followed the next day. The film was also released in [[IMAX#IMAX 3D|IMAX 3D]] format.{{cite web|title=Shrek Forever After: An IMAX 3D Experience|url=http://www.imax.com/movies/m/shrek-forever-after-an-imax-3d-experience/|work=IMAX|accessdate=August 14, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916061436/http://www.imax.com/movies/m/shrek-forever-after-an-imax-3d-experience/|archivedate=September 16, 2011|df=mdy-all}} In July 2014, the film's distribution rights were purchased by DreamWorks Animation from [[Paramount Pictures]]{{cite news|last1=Chney|first1=Alexandra|title=DreamWorks Animation Q2 Earnings Fall Short of Estimates, SEC Investigation Revealed|url=https://variety.com/2014/biz/news/dreamworks-animation-q2-earnings-fall-short-of-estimates-1201271262/|accessdate=July 30, 2014|work=Variety|date=July 29, 2014}} and transferred to [[20th Century Fox]] before reverting to [[Universal Pictures]] in 2018. ===Box office=== ''Shrek Forever After'' earned $238.7 million in North America, and $513.9 million in other countries, for a worldwide total of $752.6 million. This made it the 52nd-highest-grossing film, the [[List of highest-grossing animated films|12th-highest-grossing animated film]], the fifth-highest-grossing of 2010, the second-highest-grossing animated film of 2010 (behind ''[[Toy Story 3]]''){{cite web|title=2010 WORLDWIDE GROSSES|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=2010&p=.htm|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=October 28, 2012}} and the second-lowest-grossing film of the ''Shrek'' series.{{cite web|title=Franchises - Shrek|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/franchises/chart/?id=shrek.htm|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=January 21, 2014}} ''Shrek Forever After'' had the widest release for an animated film (4,359 theaters, later expanded to 4,389) in North America. On its opening day (May 21, 2010), it ranked No.1, grossing $20.8 million, which was lower than the opening days of the last two ''Shrek'' films. The film then opened in three days with $70.8 million, lower than box office analysts' predictions of an opening of $105 million{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2010/05/20/shrek-box-office-preview/|title='Shrek' kicks off the sure-to-be successful summer kid flick biz|work=EW.com|accessdate=October 6, 2014}} and also lower than the two previous films of the franchise. Anne Globe, head of worldwide marketing for DreamWorks Animation, said they were "happy with the film's opening" since it debuted at No. 1 and also had the fourth-best opening for an animated film, at the time, in the United States and Canada.{{cite web|url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/37302907/ns/today-entertainment/|title='Shrek Forever After' roars to top of box office|work=msnbc.com|date=May 23, 2010|accessdate=May 23, 2010}} ''Shrek Forever After'' was No.1 for three consecutive weekends.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=10783771|title='Shrek' better than 'Sex' with $43M at box office|work=abcnews.com|date=May 30, 2010|accessdate=July 11, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/37436302/ns/today-entertainment/|title='Sex' no match for 'Shrek' at box office|work=msnbc.com|date=May 31, 2010|accessdate=May 31, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6530TD20100606|title="Shrek" laughs its way past two new comedies|work=reuters.com|date=June 6, 2010|accessdate=July 11, 2010}} In North America, it was the eighth-highest-grossing film of 2010,{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?yr=2010&p=.htm|title=2010 DOMESTIC GROSSES|publisher=|accessdate=October 6, 2014}} the fourth-highest-grossing DreamWorks Animation film, 2010's third-highest-grossing animated film, trailing ''[[Toy Story 3]]'' and ''[[Despicable Me]]'' and the lowest-grossing ''Shrek'' film. Executives at DreamWorks Animation were impressed because the film earned $238.7 million in North America, although it was the fourth film in the series, seemingly being outgrown by its fans.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2010-08-31-reportcard31_CV_N.htm|title=Summer movie report card: Most pass after a rocky start|publisher=|accessdate=October 6, 2014}} Having made $513.9 million in other continents, it is the highest-grossing ''Shrek'' film, DreamWorks Animation's second-biggest hit (behind ''[[Madagascar 3: Europe's Most Wanted]]'') and the seventh-highest-grossing animated film.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118023790.html?categoryid=19&cs=1|title='Shrek 4' is DWA's biggest foreign hit|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=September 7, 2010|first=Diana|last=Lodderhose|date=September 7, 2010}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} It topped the weekend box office once on July 16–18, 2010 with $46.3 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&view=byweekend&wk=2010W29&id=shrek4.htm|title=Shrek Forever After - International Box Office Results|publisher=|accessdate=October 6, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2863&p=.htm|title=Around-the-World Roundup: 'Shrek' Is King At Last|work=boxofficemojo.com|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|first=Ray|last=Subers|date=July 20, 2010|accessdate=September 16, 2012}} In Russia and the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]], its second-highest-grossing country, it had a $19.7 million opening weekend which was a record among animated films. It earned $51.4 million in total.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/cis/opening/|title= RUSSIA - CIS ALL TIME OPENINGS|work=boxofficemojo.com|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate= September 9, 2010}} Third in total earnings came the United Kingdom, Ireland and Malta, where it opened with £8.96 million ($13.6 million) and finished its box office run with £31.1 million ($51.1 million).{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/uk/|title= United Kingdom and Ireland and Malta Box Office Index|work= boxofficemojo.com|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate= September 9, 2010}} ===Critical response=== On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], ''Shrek Forever After'' has an approval rating of 58% based on 191 reviews, with an average rating of 5.9/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "While not without its moments, ''Shrek Forever After'' too often feels like a rote rehashing of the franchise's earlier entries."{{cite web | url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/shrek_goes_fourth/ | title = Shrek Forever After Movie Reviews, Pictures |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher = [[Flixster]] |accessdate= June 12, 2010}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 58 out of 100, based on 35 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/Shrek4 | title=Shrek Forever After reviews at Metacritic.com | publisher=''[[CBS Interactive]]'' | work=Metacritic | accessdate=May 21, 2010}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale, the same score earned by ''Shrek'' and ''Shrek 2''.{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/2010/05/23/shrek-macgruber-box-office/|title='Shrek' bows to $71.2 million; 'MacGruber' sinks|publisher=}} [[Stephen Holden]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' stated "What fortifies “Shrek Forever After” are its brilliantly realized principal characters, who nearly a decade after the first “Shrek” film remain as vital and engaging fusions of image, personality and voice as any characters in the history of animation."{{cite news|author=[[Stephen Holden]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/21/movies/21shrek.html|title=I’m Green and the Kids Are a Pain, but It’s a Wonderful Life, Donkey|accessdate=May 20, 2010|work=The New York Times|date=May 20, 2010}} Pete Hammond of ''[[BoxOffice (magazine)|BoxOffice]]'' gave the film 4.5 stars out of 5, writing "Hilarious and heartfelt from start to finish, this is the best ''Shrek'' of them all, and that's no fairy tale. Borrowing liberally from [[Frank Capra]]'s ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'', this edition blends big laughs and emotion to explore what Far Far Away might have been like if Shrek never existed."{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemagazine.com/reviews/theatrical/2010-05-shrek-forever-after | author=Hammond, Pete | title=Shrek Forever After Movie Review | publisher=Boxoffice Media, LLC | date=May 5, 2010 | accessdate=May 21, 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529000106/http://www.boxofficemagazine.com/reviews/theatrical/2010-05-shrek-forever-after | archivedate=May 29, 2010 | df=mdy-all }} [[James Berardinelli]] of ''Reelviews'' awarded the film 3 out of 4 stars and wrote "Even though ''Shrek Forever After'' is obligatory and unnecessary, it's better than ''[[Shrek the Third]]'' and it's likely that most who attend as a way of saying goodbye to the Jolly Green Ogre will not find themselves wishing they had sought out a more profitable way of spending 90-odd minutes."{{cite web|url=http://www.reelviews.net/php_review_template.php?identifier=2084 | author=Berardinelli, James | title=Shrek Forever After - A movie review by James Berardinelli | publisher=''Reelviews'' | date=May 19, 2010 | accessdate=May 21, 2010}} James White of ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' gave the film four out of four stars, saying "DreamWorks could be entering a period of fresh creativity. With How To Train Your Dragon and a balanced, darker-hued and very funny Shrek finale, they've found the magic again."{{cite web|title=Shrek Forever After Review|url=https://www.empireonline.com/movies/shrek-forever/review/}} Lisa Schwarzbaum of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film a "B−" grade, saying "Everyone involved fulfills his or her job requirements adequately. But the magic is gone and ''Shrek Forever After'' is no longer an ogre phenomenon to reckon with."{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20386387,00.html | author=Schwarzbaum, Lisa | title=Shrek Forever After – Movie – EW.com | publisher=''Entertainment Weekly'' | date=May 20, 2010 | accessdate=May 21, 2010}} [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' wrote "It's a fun ride. What's missing is the excitement of a new interpretation."{{cite news|last=Travers|first=Peter|title=Shrek Forever After|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/shrek-forever-after-20100520|accessdate=April 8, 2012|newspaper=Rolling Stone|date=May 20, 2010}} Mary Pols of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' concluded her review with "Can an ogre [[jumping the shark|jump a shark]]? I think so."{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1990874,00.html#ixzz0oaiIL8h0 | author=Pols, Mary | title=Shrek Forever After: An Ogre in Midlife Crisis | publisher=''Time, Inc.'' | date=May 20, 2010 | accessdate=May 21, 2010}} Giving the film 1 star out of 4, [[Kyle Smith]] of the ''[[New York Post]]'' wrote "After the frantic spurt of fairy-tale allusions and jokes in the first three ''Shrek''s, this one inches along with a few mostly pointless action scenes and the occasional mild pun."{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/movies/shrek_from_page_Kx2OHEjVoKj8E2aY5p92BJ#ixzz0oajZGqqQ | title=Fourth 'Shrek' is pure drek | publisher=''NYP Holdings, Inc.'' | work=[[The New York Post]] | date=May 21, 2010 | accessdate=May 21, 2010 | first=Kyle | last=Smith}} ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable" ! Award ! Category/Recipient(s) ! Result ! References |- |[[Teen Choice Awards 2010]] |Choice Movie: Animated Film |rowspan="9" {{nom}} | align="center" |{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2010/06/14/first-wave-of-teen-choice-2010-nominees-announced/20100614fox01/|title=First Wave of "Teen Choice 2010" Nominees Announced|date=June 14, 2010|work=The Futon Critic|accessdate=June 15, 2010}}{{cite web | title = Winners of 'Teen Choice 2010' Awards Announced; Teens Cast More Than 85 Million Votes | url = http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/08/08/winners-of-teen-choice-2010-awards-announced-teens-cast-more-than-85-million-votes/59453}} |- |[[Nickelodeon Australian Kids' Choice Awards 2010]] |Favorite Movie | align="center" |[http://www.thehothits.com/news/19942/nickelodeon-kids'-choice-awards-nominations---australia-2010! Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards Nominations - Australia 2010!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920190709/http://www.thehothits.com/news/19942/nickelodeon-kids%27-choice-awards-nominations---australia-2010%21 |date=September 20, 2011 }} ''[[Take40 Australia]]''. Retrieved October 9, 2010. |- |[[37th People's Choice Awards]] |Favorite Family Movie | align="center" |{{cite web|url=http://www.peopleschoice.com/pca/awards/nominees/index.jsp?year=2011|title=2011 People's Choice Awards Nominations|publisher=|accessdate=October 6, 2014}} |- | rowspan="5" | [[38th Annie Awards]] |Animated Effects in an Animated Production | rowspan="5" align="center" |{{cite web|title=38th Annual Annie Nominations|url=http://annieawards.org/legacy38th.html|publisher=The Annie Awards|accessdate=April 6, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111216232924/http://annieawards.org/legacy38th.html|archivedate=December 16, 2011|df=mdy-all}} |- |Music in a Feature Production |- |Voice Acting in a Feature Production (Cameron Diaz) |- |Storyboarding in a Feature Production |- |Production Design in a Feature Production |- | rowspan="3" |[[2011 Kids' Choice Awards]] |Favorite Animated Film | align="center" |[http://blog.zap2it.com/pop2it/2011/02/kids-choice-awards-2011-nominees-miley-cyrus-justin-bieber-and-selena-gomez-lead.html Kids' Choice Awards 2011 Nominees: Miley Cyrus, Justin Bieber and Selena Gomez lead] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322071437/http://blog.zap2it.com/pop2it/2011/02/kids-choice-awards-2011-nominees-miley-cyrus-justin-bieber-and-selena-gomez-lead.html |date=March 22, 2012 }} Retrieved February 11, 2011. |- |Favorite Voice From An Animated Movie (Eddie Murphy) |{{won}} | align="center" |[http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/04/02/kids-choice-awards-nickelodeon/ 'Kids' Choice Awards': Goo had it coming, Jim Carrey and Russell Brand!] Retrieved April 3, 2011. |- |Favorite Voice From An Animated Movie (Cameron Diaz) |rowspan="4" {{nom}} | align="center" |[http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20465123,00.html?xid=rss-fullcontent Cameron Diaz Is 'Flattered' By Kids Choice Nomination] Retrieved February 11, 2011. |- |[[37th Saturn Awards]] |Best Animated Film | align="center" | {{cite web|url=http://scifimafia.com/2011/02/37th-annual-saturn-award-nominations/|title=37th Annual Saturn Award Nominations|work=SciFi Mafia|accessdate=October 6, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430224049/http://scifimafia.com/2011/02/37th-annual-saturn-award-nominations/|archivedate=April 30, 2011|df=mdy-all}} |- | rowspan="2" | [[9th Visual Effects Society Awards]] |Outstanding Animation in an Animated Feature Motion Picture (Jason Reisig, Doug Cooper, [[Gina Shay]], [[Teresa Cheng]]) |rowspan="2" | {{cite web|url=https://www.visualeffectssociety.com/ayear/9th-annual-ves-awards|title=9th Annual VES Awards|work=visual effects society|accessdate=December 22, 2017}} |- |Outstanding Effects Animation in an Animated Feature Motion Picture (Jeff Budsberg, Andrew Kim, Yancy Lindquist, Can Yuksel) |} ===Home media=== ''Shrek Forever After'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray]] on December 7, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=5273|title=Shrek Forever After and Collection Blu-ray in December|author=Juan Colange|work=Blu-ray.com|date=October 8, 2010|accessdate=December 10, 2010}} As of April 24, 2011, the movie has made $75 million in DVD and Blu-ray sales.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2010/SHRK4-DVD.php|title=Shrek Forever After - DVD Sales|publisher=|accessdate=October 6, 2014}} The film is also included in ''Shrek: The Whole Story'', a box set released on the same day that included all four [[Shrek (franchise)#Film series|''Shrek'' movies]] and additional bonus content. ==Video game== {{main|Shrek Forever After (video game)}} ''Shrek Forever After'' is an [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure video game]] based on the movie of the same name. It was released by [[Activision]] on May 18, 2010. ==Possible sequel== In February 2014, in an interview with [[Fox Business Network]], Katzenberg hinted that a fifth film still may be made, saying, "We like to let [the characters] have a little bit of time to rest. But I think you can be confident that we'll have another chapter in the Shrek series. We're not finished and, more importantly, neither is he."{{cite news|last=McNary|first=Dave|title=DreamWorks Animation CEO Hints at Another 'Shrek' Movie|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/jeffrey-katzenberg-hints-at-another-shrek-movie-1201119510/|accessdate=February 25, 2014|newspaper=Variety|date=February 24, 2014}} On June 15, 2016, after [[NBCUniversal]] purchased DreamWorks Animation for $3.8 billion, NBCUniversal's president and chief executive officer [[Steve Burke (businessman)|Steve Burke]] discussed plans to revive the franchise, as well as other DreamWorks films.{{cite web|last1=Lieberman|first1=David|title=NBCU Chief Looks To Revive 'Shrek' And Sales From DreamWorks Animation Deal|url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/steve-burke-nbcuniversal-revive-shrek-sales-dreamworks-animation-deal-1201772640/|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=September 3, 2016|date=June 14, 2016}} In July 2016, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' cited sources saying that a fifth film was planned for a 2019 release.{{cite news|last=Masters|first=Kim|title=Jeffrey Katzenberg Plots Next Act as Universal Faces DreamWorks Questions|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jeffrey-katzenberg-plots-next-act-912484|accessdate=July 21, 2016|newspaper=Hollywood Reporter|date=July 20, 2016}} In September 2016, Eddie Murphy confirmed that the film was expected to be released in 2019 or 2020, and that the script had been completed. In October 2016, [[Mike Mitchell (director)|Mike Mitchell]] stated that ''[[Austin Powers (film series)|Austin Powers]]'' screenwriter [[Michael McCullers]] had written a script based on his own original idea.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehollywoodnews.com/2016/10/17/exclusive-writer-revealed-dreamworks-shrek-5-sky-high-2-coming/|title=Exclusive: Story writer revealed for Dreamworks' 'Shrek 5' - 'Sky High 2' coming?|first=Paul|last=Heath|date=October 17, 2016|publisher=The Hollywood News}} In March 2017, asked about the script, McCullers said it featured "a pretty big reinvention" for the film series.{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/boss-baby-screenwriter-trump-references-office-jokes-shrek-5-q-a-990421|title='Boss Baby' Screenwriter on Skewering Corporate Culture and All Those (Coincidental) Trump References|first=Ashley|last=Lee|date=March 31, 2017|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter}} On November 6, 2018, it was reported by ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' that [[Illumination Entertainment]]'s [[CEO]] and founder [[Chris Meledandri]] had been tasked by Universal Pictures to revive both ''Shrek'' and ''Puss in Boots'' film series, with the original cast potentially returning.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/shrek-puss-in-boots-reboot-1203020785/|title=‘Shrek,’ ‘Puss in Boots’ Getting Rebooted (EXCLUSIVE)|last=Staff|first=Variety|date=2018-11-06|work=Variety|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}{{cite web|title=‘Shrek’ & ‘Puss in Boots’ Rebooting at Universal with Chris Meledandri|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/features/shrek-puss-in-boots-rebooting-at-universal-with-chris-meledandri/|website=Animation Magazine|accessdate=November 6, 2018|date=November 6, 2018}} ==Spin-off== {{main|Puss in Boots (2011 film)}} ''[[Puss in Boots (2011 film)|Puss in Boots]]'' is a [[Computer animation|computer-animated]] feature film that was released on October 28, 2011.{{cite news|title=Holiday Movie Release Date Moves: A Recap|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/09/release-date-moves-a-recap/|accessdate=October 2, 2011|newspaper=Deadline|date=September 30, 2011}} The movie is based on and follows the character of the same name on his adventures with [[List of Shrek characters#Kitty Softpaws|Kitty Softpaws]] and mastermind [[List of Shrek characters#Humpty Dumpty|Humpty Dumpty]] before his first appearance in ''Shrek 2''.{{cite news |title=DreamWorks Animation Announces Feature Film Release Slate Through 2014 |url=http://ir.dreamworksanimation.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=555383 |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |newspaper=DreamWorks Animation |date=March 8, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/614v7Q4g4?url=http://ir.dreamworksanimation.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=555383 |archivedate=August 20, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} revision.text:
[[File:Stuart Smalley.jpg|thumb|300px|Stuart Smalley]] '''Stuart Smalley''' is a fictional character invented and performed by comedian and satirist [[Al Franken]]. The character originated on the television show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', in a mock [[self-help]] show called "Daily Affirmations With Stuart Smalley." It first aired on the show's February 9, 1991 episode hosted by [[Kevin Bacon]]. Stuart is Franken's middle name.<ref>[http://www.nndb.com/people/476/000022410/ Al Franken], NNDB.com</ref> Franken has stated that his "going to [[Al-Anon]] meetings inspired [the character] Stuart [Smalley]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3xqKkLlCfLE&t=20s|title=STUART SMALLEY BORN FROM AL-ANON MEETING|first=|last=ArtisanNewsService|date=3 May 2007|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> (He attended the meetings in support of his wife, who was battling alcoholism at the time.)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/13/magazine/al-franken-faces-donald-trump-and-the-next-four-years.html|title=Al Franken Faces Donald Trump and the Next Four Years|first=Mark|last=Leibovich|date=13 December 2016|publisher=|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref>
==Character== Stuart participates in many (sometimes fictional) programs, not limited to [[Overeaters Anonymous]], Children of Alcoholic Parents Anonymous, and Children of Rageaholic Parents Anonymous. He is an [[effeminate]] man with a perfectly coiffed bleached-blond hairdo, who regularly wears a yellow button-down shirt with a powder blue cardigan.
It is frequently hinted that Stuart may be [[gay]], but his [[sexual orientation]] is never clearly stated. All his romantic partners have names which could be male or female, like Dale, Chris, or Merle. His father gripes, "You'd drink too if you had [[Liberace]] for a son." <!-- One character who becomes a romantic interest in the novel appears in the movie, where the character is played by a man; however, in the movie, nothing indicates that the two characters ever meet outside the courtroom, let alone develop romantic interest in each other. -->
Within the context of the show, Stuart is quick to point out that he is ''not'' a licensed therapist but relies instead upon the credibility of his own experiences as a non-professional. His guests are very often celebrities; however, Smalley is seemingly unaware of his guests' fame as he never uses their full names so as to "protect (their) anonymity."
Other guests who appeared were his family members, such as [[Macaulay Culkin]] playing his nephew or [[Roseanne Barr]] playing his sister, who suffers from [[battered wife syndrome]]. One Canadian relative named Leon Smalley and played by [[Kiefer Sutherland]] also had a show called "Today's Meditation", which became a big hit in [[Canada]]. Although he is clearly a copycat of Stuart, Leon does seem more self-confident on his show, which could be a reason for his greater success.
The character was popular enough to spawn a 1992 novel, ''I'm Good Enough, I'm Smart Enough, and Doggone It, People Like Me!: Daily Affirmations with Stuart Smalley''. The book keeps in line with the concept of the character, and is presented ([[tongue-in-cheek]]) as a legitimate day-to-day affirmation book. Each page is dated and the reader is "supposed" to follow through as if they were actually seeking help. Naturally, however, things go wrong in the writing process, and thus the affirmations branch off into Stuart's own commentary about what a hard time he is having writing it, etc. He also discusses his past relationship with ex-significant-other Dale, "the Rageaholic".
An [[audiobook]] was also released, ''You're Good Enough, You're Smart Enough, and Doggone It, People Like You''. The content of this audio book was completely different from the printed one, but followed through on the same gag. The tapes played guided visualizations meant to help the listener relax and focus; however, Stuart makes a vow at the beginning not to make any edits or corrections in the recording process because "I'm a perfectionist and if I start making changes, I'll never stop." As such it is full of humorous errors, including one gag in which Stuart tells his listeners who are driving to work to "close their eyes and envision..." something. (As such, there is a warning label on the box that says, "Do not listen while driving," a joke that doesn't make sense until one has actually listened to the tape.)
As the character's popularity increased, a film was released called ''[[Stuart Saves His Family]]''. It chronicled the life Stuart leads and his relationship with a very [[dysfunctional family]]. His alcoholic father and enabling mother, overweight sister and equally alcoholic brother call upon him when an aunt dies. He is asked to oversee the sale of her home, bringing much-needed money to all of the family. At the same time, his public access self-help show is canceled. Naturally, things go awry, and he must learn to deal with himself and his own life before he can attempt to help others. While many critics praised the film, including [[Gene Siskel]] (who awarded the film 3.5 stars out of four, in his print review) and [[Roger Ebert]], the film was financially unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/section/movies|title=Movies|publisher=|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref>
According to a March 1995 article in ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine, Franken regularly lobbied to get the Smalley character on the air more in his last season on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.
The character effectively disappeared after the box-office failure of the film and Franken's exit from ''Saturday Night Live'', save one appearance where Smalley, bitter over the failure of the movie, refused to finish his affirmation, excoriated his viewers for not watching, and openly wept. At one point in that skit, Smalley (in reference to the film, its glowing reviews, and the film that beat it) commented: "But you didn't want 'funny' and 'poignant'. You wanted 'Dumb....and Dumber....and Dumber....and Dumber'!" In 2002, Franken reprised the Smalley character again when [[Al Gore]] hosted, in which he mentioned that his father was still an alcoholic.
The character also showed up from time to time on ''[[The Al Franken Show]]''. Later, after Franken made a [[United States Senate election in Minnesota, 2008|bid]] for a [[United States Senate]] seat that ended in success but also in controversy – he would not be officially declared the winner, and therefore under Minnesota law could not be seated, until a full eight months after the election itself – he would be dubbed "Senator Stuart Smalley" by critics and fans alike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/archive/Will-Anyone-Remember-Stuart-Smalley.html|title=Franken In, Bunning Out: Senate as Second Act|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/riptide/2009/06/al_franken_finally_wins_karma.php|title=Al Franken Finally Wins, Karma Makes Up For 2000 Florida Election Fiasco|first=Kyle|last=Munzenrieder|date=30 June 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
==Catchphrases== {{Importance section|date=September 2017}} The character is known for a number of [[catchphrase]]s, many of which are chosen not just for comic effect, but to play on a perceived tendency of the self-help movement to talk and think in [[Psychobabble (jargon)|psychobabble]]. Some, such as the phrase "stinkin' thinkin'", are taken from common 12-step slogans. * "I'm good enough, I'm smart enough, and doggone it, people like me." * "That's just stinkin' thinkin!" * "You're should-ing all over yourself." * "[[Nile|Denial]] ain't just a river in [[Egypt]]!" * "I am a worthy human being." * "...and that's...okay." * "Trace it, face it, and erase it." * "I don't know what I'm doing. They're gonna cancel the show. I'm gonna die homeless and penniless and twenty pounds overweight and no one will ever love me." * "I'm in a shame spiral." * "You're only as sick as your secrets." * "Compare and despair." * "You need a checkup from the neckup." * "I am a human being, not a human doing." * "[[Pee-wee Herman]]: There but for the grace of God go I." * "It’s easier to put on slippers than to carpet the whole world."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edgemagazine.net/2003/03/stuart-smalley/|title=Stuart Saves His Country: An interview with Al Franken and Stuart Smalley|publisher=}}</ref> * "Labels disable."

{{About|the comic book series|other uses|Crow (disambiguation)}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox comics character and title | image = The Crow1 Cover.jpg | converted = y | alt = Eric | caption = ''The Crow'' #1 (February 1989). | alter_ego = Eric | publisher = [[Caliber Press]], [[Kitchen Sink Press]], [[Image Comics]], [[IDW Publishing]] | debut = ''Caliber Presents'' #1 (Jan. 1989) | creators = [[James O'Barr]] | powers = *Enhanced strength, speed, and [[agility]] *Cat-like reflexes *Heightened senses *Resistance to injury or pain *Complete Invulnerability |cvr_image = |cvr_caption = |cvr_alt = |schedule = |format = |limited = Y |ongoing = Y |1shot = Y |genre = [[Gothic fiction]] |pub_series = [[Caliber Press]] (1989–1990)
[[Kitchen Sink Press]] (1996–1998)
[[Image Comics]] (1999)
[[IDW Publishing]] (2012–2014) |date = |1stishhead = The Crow (Caliber Press) |1stishyr = 1989 |1stishmo = Feb. |endishyr = 1989 |endishmo = May |1stishhead1 = The Crow: Dead Time |1stishyr1 = 1996 |1stishmo1 = Jan. |endishyr1 = 1996 |endishmo1 = Mar. |1stishhead2 = The Crow: Flesh & Blood |1stishyr2 = 1996 |1stishmo2 = May |endishyr2 = 1996 |endishmo2 = July |1stishhead3 = The Crow: Wild Justice |1stishyr3 = 1996 |1stishmo3 = Oct. |endishyr3 = 1996 |endishmo3 = Dec. |1stishhead4 = The Crow: Waking Nightmares |1stishyr4 = 1997 |1stishmo4 = Jan. |endishyr4 = 1988 |endishmo4 = May |1stishhead5 = The Crow / Razor: Kill the Pain |1stishyr5 = 1998 |1stishmo5 = Apr. |endishyr5 = 1988 |endishmo5 = Sept. |1stishhead6 = The Crow (Image Comics) |1stishyr6 = 1999 |1stishmo6 = Feb. |endishyr6 = 1989 |endishmo6 = Nov. |1stishhead7 = The Crow: Death and Rebirth |1stishyr7 = 2012 |1stishmo7 = July |endishyr7 = 2012 |endishmo7 = Nov. |1stishhead8 = The Crow: Curare |1stishyr8 = 2013 |1stishmo8 = June |endishyr8 = 2013 |endishmo8 = Aug. |1stishhead9 = The Crow: Pestilence |1stishyr9 = 2014 |1stishmo9 = Mar. |endishyr9 = 2014 |endishmo9 = June |issues = 45+ |main_char_team = Eric
Shelly |writers = [[James O'Barr]], [[John Wagner]], [[James Vance (comics)|James Vance]], [[Jerry Prosser]], [[Christopher Golden]], [[Everette Hartsoe]], [[Jon J Muth]], John Shirley, Frank Bill |artists = [[James O'Barr]], [[Alexander Maleev]], [[Charlie Adlard]], Jamie Tolagson, [[Paul Lee (artist)|Paul Lee]], [[Kevin Colden]], Antoine Dodé, Drew Moss |pencillers = [[Phil Hester (comics)|Philip Hester]] |inkers = Andé Parks |letterers = |colorists = |editors = |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators_series = |CEheader = |TPB = The Crow: Special Edition |ISBN = 978-1451627251 |nonUS = ]}} '''''The Crow''''' is a [[Superhero comics|superhero]] [[comic book]] [[ongoing series|series]] created by [[James O'Barr]] revolving around the titular character of the same name. The series, which was originally created by O'Barr as a means of dealing with the death of his girlfriend at the hands of a drunk driver,{{cite web|url=http://www.thing.net/~lilyvac/writing35.html |title=DIKE BLAIR | Writing |publisher=Thing.net |date= |accessdate=2011-01-12}} was first published by [[Caliber Comics]] in 1989. It became an underground success, and was later adapted into [[The Crow (1994 film)|a film of the same name]] in [[1994 in film|1994]]. Three film sequels, a television series, and numerous books and comic books (published by numerous companies) have also been subsequently produced. ''The Crow'' has been translated into almost a dozen languages and has sold around 750,000 copies worldwide.{{Cite web | title = The Crow Translations | url = http://www.jamesobarr.net/word.asp?cat=1&id=67 | accessdate =2010-02-05 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080415173217/http://www.jamesobarr.net/word.asp?cat=1&id=67 | archivedate = 2008-04-15 }} == Publication history == === Caliber Press === [[File:Deadworld 10.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''Deadworld'' #10 (1988) back cover. Art by James O'Barr.]] The Crow first appeared on the back cover of ''Deadworld'' #10 (November 1988); James O'Barr provided a back cover to the first comic book Caliber Press published, which contained an advertisement for the upcoming The Crow appearance in ''Caliber Presents'' #1. (The ads shows The Crow standing with a smoking shotgun in one hand and a samurai sword in the other, with the statement, "For Some Things...There Is No Forgiveness". It mentions The Crow appearing in February 1989.) The Crow's first in-story appearance was in ''Caliber Presents'' #1 (January 1989), in the story "Inertia", which serves as a prequel to the main series. O'Barr again provided a back cover for this issue. The character's first limited series was ''The Crow'' #1-4 (Feb.–May 1989). Four issues, titled "Pain", "Fear", "Irony", and "Despair," take readers through a series of vengeance tales as The Crow cuts and shoots through Tin Tin, Tom Tom, Top Dollar, Funboy and T-Bird, the gang members that attacked and killed him and his lover Shelly. In ''A Caliber Christmas'' (Dec. 1989), Eric reflects back on happier times with Shelly in the story "Atmosphere." (In ''The Crow'' graphic novel, this story is placed between issues #2 and 3.) ''Caliber Presents'' #15 (Sept. 1990) contained a preview of the unpublished ''The Crow'' #5, titled "Death", that was meant to complete the original story arc. === Tundra Publishing === [[Tundra Publishing]] later reprinted Caliber's first four issues in two double-sized volumes and printed "Death" (also double-sized) as the third volume. === Kitchen Sink Press === From 1996-1998, [[Kitchen Sink Press]] published five [[Limited series (comics)|mini-series]] and a [[one-shot (comics)|one-shot]] based on The Crow concept with a new avatar in each series. === London Night Studios === Following the Kitchen Sink series, [[London Night Studios]] published ''The Crow/Razor: Kill the Pain'' in 1998, which saw Eric Draven paired with [[Everette Hartsoe]]'s [[bad girl art|bad girl]] character [[Razor (character)|Razor]]. === Image Comics === In 1999, [[Image Comics]] released a new ''Crow'' comic series with yet another take on the Eric Draven story. It ran for ten issues, ending in November of that year. === Titan Books === In 2002, [[Titan Books]] compiled and released the previous original books into one, making this the first time The Crow appeared as a single book === Gallery Books === O'Barr stated in a 2004 interview that an Author's Edition would contain at least "60 pages of new material that no one has ever seen. Half of that are pages that had to be removed for space reasons." O'Barr described the additions as including "more romance flashback scenes between Eric and Shelly," as well as sequences that would make the work "more visually interesting."{{cite web|url=http://suicidegirls.com/interviews/James+OBarr+creator+of+The+Crow/|title=James O'Barr, creator of The Crow|last=Epstein|first=Daniel Robert|date=May 21, 2004|publisher=Suicide Girls|accessdate=2008-04-24}} [http://suicidegirls.com/interviews/James Archived]{{dead link|date=February 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} on 2008-04-24. On January 16, 2010, it was announced on O'Barr's official website that the Author's Edition of ''The Crow'' was indeed going to be released and that O'Barr was currently working on it.{{cite web|url=http://jamesobarr.typepad.com/my_weblog/2010/01/the-big-news.html|title=The Crow Author's Edition|date=January 16, 2010|publisher=James O'Barr|accessdate=2010-01-18}} On April 7, 2011, O'Barr announced that ''The Crow: Special Edition'' would be released on July 28, 2011, from [[Gallery Publishing Group|Gallery Books]].O'Barr, James. [http://jamesobarr.typepad.com/my_weblog/2011/04/the-crow-special-edition-release-date.html "'The Crow: Special Edition' release date!"] James O'Barr blog (April 7, 2011). === IDW Publishing === In July 2012, [[IDW Publishing]] published a new five-issue Crow series, ''The Crow: Death and Rebirth'', written by novelist [[John Shirley]] (co-writer of the original Crow film) and illustrated by [[Kevin Colden]].{{Cite web | title = Preview of The Crow #1 (IDW) | author = The Comic Book Critic | url = http://comicbookcritic.net/2012/04/13/preview-crow-idw-kevin-colden/ | accessdate =2012-04-17 }} Four more IDW ''Crow'' series followed: ''The Crow: Skinning the Wolves'' (2013), ''The Crow: Curare'' (2013), ''The Crow: Pestilence'' (2014) and ''The Crow: Momento Mori'' (2018). ==Plot== The story revolves around an unfortunate young man named Eric. He and his fiancée, Shelly, are assaulted by a gang of street thugs after their car breaks down. Eric is shot in the head and is [[paralysis|paralyzed]], and can only watch as Shelly is savagely beaten, [[raped]], and shot in the head. They are then left for dead on the side of the road. Eric later dies in the hospital operating room while Shelly is [[dead on arrival|DOA]]. He is resurrected by a crow and seeks vengeance on the [[murder]]ers, methodically stalking and killing them. When not on the hunt, Eric stays in the house he shared with Shelly, spending most of his time there lost in memories of her. Her absence is torture for him; he is in emotional pain, even engaging in [[self-harm|self-mutilation]] by cutting himself. The crow acts as both guide and goad for Eric, giving him information that helps him in his quest but also chastising him for dwelling on Shelly's death, seeing his pining as useless self-indulgence that distracts him from his purpose. ==Characters== {{For|a list of protagonists in spin-off comics, novels, film and television adaptations|Crow (comics)}} * Shelly: Fiancée of Eric who gets raped and killed by T-Bird's gang. She appears in Eric's dreams and memories. * Sherri: A young street girl whom Eric meets while going after Funboy. Sherri is shown as upset, due to her mother not being there for her, and even goes so far as to tell Eric that she believes she's been bad and God sent her to Hell. She and Eric seem to bond closely, and feeling sorry for her, he gives her Shelly's engagement ring. She's overjoyed, because no one has ever given her a gift before, and she calls him a "clown", while he calls her a "princess". She is renamed Sarah in the film adaptation. * T-Bird: The head of the gang that murders Shelly and Eric. * Funboy: T-Bird's right-hand man, a morphine addict who is sleeping with Sherri's mother. * Top Dollar: A low-level drug dealer, who also participated in gang-raping Shelly; in the film adaptation, he is the main antagonist rather than T-Bird. * Tin-Tin: The first of T-Bird's gang to be eliminated by Eric. * Tom-Tom: Another of T-Bird's soldiers and one of Shelly's rapists, whom Eric interrogates over the whereabouts of Shelly's ring. Tom-Tom is absent from the film adaptation as his role is largely condensed with another book character, Skank. * Gideon: A pawnbroker who fences Shelly's engagement ring after it is given to him by T-Bird; in the film adaptation, Tin-Tin gives him the ring. * Officer Albrecht: A beat cop who confronts Eric outside Gideon's pawnshop. * Captain Hook: The [[detective]] who originally handled Eric and Shelly's case. Eric sends him his regards through Albrecht. ==Critical reception== ''The Crow'' is ranked 37th in [[IGN]]'s Top 100 Comic Book Heroes.[http://uk.ign.com/top/comic-book-heroes/37 The Crow - #37 Top Comic Book Heroes - IGN] In 2005, creator James O'Barr claimed that ''The Crow'' was: *The best-selling independent black-and-white graphic novel of all time. *Translated into almost a dozen languages and has sold over a quarter-million copies worldwide. *The second American comic book to get its author the "Storyteller Award" by the [[Angoulême International Comics Festival]] held annually in [[Angoulême]], [[France]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20080913012157/http://www.jamesobarr.net/word.asp?cat=1&id=67 CrowFansOnline and James O'Barr - the official fansite of the creator of The Crow] == In other media == ===Film=== In 1994, a film based on the comic (titled ''[[The Crow (1994 film)|The Crow]]'') was released to theaters by [[Miramax Films]]. The film was both a critical and commercial success, earning $50,693,129{{Cite web | title = The Crow| url = http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=crow.htm| accessdate =2010-01-23 }} total gross during its 1994 United States theatrical release. A cult following, in part due to the accidental death of its star [[Brandon Lee]] on the film's set, has maintained the film's popularity, with a regular staple of movie memorabilia being found at retailers like [[Hot Topic]]. Three sequels have been made so far: ''[[The Crow: City of Angels]]'' (1996), starring [[Vincent Pérez]] (as The Crow), [[Mia Kirshner]], [[Richard Brooks (actor)|Richard Brooks]] and [[Iggy Pop]]; ''[[The Crow: Salvation]]'' (2000), starring [[Eric Mabius]] (as The Crow), [[Kirsten Dunst]] and [[Fred Ward]]; and ''[[The Crow: Wicked Prayer]]'' (2005), starring [[Edward Furlong]] (as The Crow), [[David Boreanaz]] and [[Tara Reid]]. In the late 1990s, a sequel/reboot to ''The Crow'' entitled ''The Crow: 2037'' was in the works; it would be set in the future. It was written and scheduled to be directed by [[Rob Zombie]], but it was ultimately cancelled.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1428859/zombie-will-write-direct-next-crow-flick.jhtml |title=Zombie Will Write/Direct Next "Crow" Flick – Music, Celebrity, Artist News |publisher=''MTV'' |date=1997-02-11 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.experts123.com/q/what-happened-to-the-rob-zombie-script-for-crow-2037.html |title=What happened to the Rob Zombie script for Crow: 2037? |publisher=Experts123.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.roteirodecinema.com.br/scripts/files/crow_2037_a_new_world_of_gods_and_monster.htm |title=Scripts on the Net – The Crow: 2037 A New World of Gods and Monster, by Rob Zombie – Read The Screenplay |publisher=Roteirodecinema.com.br |date=2008-09-22 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}{{cite web|url=http://io9.com/5932803/100-wonderful-and-terrible-movies-that-never-existed |title=100 Wonderful and Terrible Movies That Never Existed |publisher=Io9.com |date=2012-08-10 |accessdate=2012-11-24}} On December 14, 2008, [[Stephen Norrington]] announced in ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' that he planned to write and direct a "reinvention" of ''The Crow''. Norrington distinguished between the original and his remake: "Whereas Proyas’ original was gloriously Gothic and stylized, the new movie will be realistic, hard-edged and mysterious, almost documentary-style."{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117997365.html?categoryId=1350&cs=1 | work=Variety | title=Norrington flies with 'Crow' franchise | first=Michael | last=Fleming | date=2008-12-14}} In 2009 [[Ryan Kavanaugh]]'s [[Relativity Media]] was negotiating with [[Edward R. Pressman]] for both the film's rights and financing.{{Cite web|title = The Crow Relaunch Moves Forward With Casting | work = | publisher = [[i09]] | date = | url = http://io9.com/5410643/the-crow-relaunch-moves-forward-with-casting | format = | doi = | accessdate =2009-11-25 }} In May 2013, actor [[Luke Evans (actor)|Luke Evans]] accepted the role of Eric Draven, with [[F. Javier Gutiérrez]] set to direct. According to James O'Barr the movie is expected to be much more faithful to the comic including flashbacks, metaphors, horses, trains and barbed wire, making it not suitable for younger audiences.{{Cite web|title = NYCC 2014: Twenty Years Of ‘The Crow’ With James O’Barr|work = IGN | date = 2014-10-10 | url = http://www.geeksofdoom.com/2014/10/10/nycc-2014-twenty-years-of-the-crow-with-james-obarr |accessdate =2014-11-15}} Director Javier Gutiérrez also confirmed that his intentions are to create literally a page-by-page adaptation of the movie.{{Cite web|first=Sean CW|last=Korsgaard|title=Interview with James O'Barr, creator of The Crow|website=korsgaardscommentary.com|date=October 30, 2014|url=http://www.korsgaardscommentary.com/2014/10/interview-james-obarr-creator-crow.html|accessdate=November 15, 2014}} Filming was slated to start in the spring of 2015{{Cite web | last= | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Crow Reboot to Start Shooting in Spring 2015 | work = IGN | date = 2014-10-24 | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/10/25/the-crow-reboot-to-start-shooting-in-spring-2015 | doi = | accessdate =2014-11-15 }} but on July 31, 2015, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' reported that production on the reboot stalled because of Relativity Media's bankruptcy.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/relativity-fallout-crow-remake-sees-812413|title=Relativity Fallout: 'The Crow' Remake Sees Pre-Production Stall|work=The Hollywood Reporter|last=Ritman|first=Alex|date=July 31, 2015}} [[Corin Hardy]] was the next director to take on the film and O'Barr said in October 2017: {{quote|As of right now, it's slated to start pre-production in February with a very talented British director named Corin Hardy. I'm involved in every aspect of the film and working closely with the director.{{Cite web |url=https://www.screengeek.net/2017/10/29/the-crow-reboot-to-begin-pre-production-in-february/ |title=Exclusive: The Crow Reboot To Begin Pre-Production In February |last=Salcido |first=Mark |date=2017-10-29 |website=Screengeek |access-date=2017-10-30}}}} On May 31, 2018, it was announced that both director Hardy and star Jason Mamoa had exited the project.{{Cite news|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/the-crow-remake-dead/|title='The Crow' Remake is Dead Again as Jason Momoa and Corin Hardy Exit|date=2018-05-31|work=/Film|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}} ===Television=== A [[television]] series, ''[[The Crow: Stairway to Heaven]]'' (1998), was based on the first movie with [[Mark Dacascos]] replacing Lee in the role of Eric Draven. === Novels and story collections === From 1996–2001, a number of novels based on the world and thematic concerns of The Crow were published, mostly by [[Harper (publisher)|Harper]]. Authors of these novels included such notable names as [[Chet Williamson]], [[David Bischoff]], [[Poppy Z. Brite]], [[S. P. Somtow]], [[Norman Partridge]], and [[A. A. Attanasio]]. In 1998, O'Barr and editor [[Ed Kramer]] asked an array of [[fiction]] writers, poets, and artists — including [[Gene Wolfe]], [[Alan Dean Foster]], [[Charles de Lint]], [[Jack Dann]], [[Jane Yolen]], [[Henry Rollins]] and [[Iggy Pop]] — to interpret this [[Gothic fiction]] phenomenon. ''The Crow: Shattered Lives and Broken Dreams''[http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-345-41711-4 ''The Crow: Shattered Lives & Broken Dreams'' review], ''Publishers Weekly''. Accessed Oct. 27, 2016. was released by [[Random House]] on Halloween; and a year later, in a limited signed and numbered volume, by [[Donald M. Grant|Donald M. Grant Publishing]]. === Video games === ''[[The Crow: City of Angels (video game)|The Crow: City of Angels]]'' is a 1997 action [[video game]] for [[Sega Saturn]], [[Sony PlayStation]] and [[Microsoft Windows]]. It is loosely based on the [[The Crow: City of Angels|movie of the same title]]. The player assumes the role of the hero of the film, Ashe Corven. It received negative reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps/197002-the-crow-city-of-angels/index.html |title=The Crow: City of Angels |publisher=Game Rankings |date=1997-02-28 |accessdate=2011-01-13}}''GamePro'' 95 (June 1997), page 76. === Music === There have been five albums of music related to ''The Crow'' and its attendant films: * ''[[Fear and Bullets]]'' (1994) — an album created through a collaboration between James O'Barr and longtime friend [[John Bergin]] as a soundtrack to O'Barr's graphic novel ''The Crow.'' It was originally released in 1994 along with a limited edition hardcover copy of the graphic novel. * ''[[The Crow: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]]'' (1994) — showcases the film's music by popular artists * ''[[The Crow: Original Motion Picture Score]]'' (1994) — original music written by [[Graeme Revell]] for the film ''[[The Crow (1994 film)|The Crow]]''; not to be confused with the soundtrack album, above * ''[[The Crow: City of Angels (soundtrack)|The Crow: City of Angels]]'' (1996) — soundtrack to the [[The Crow: City of Angels|film of the same name]]; features a cover of the [[Fleetwood Mac]] song "[[Gold Dust Woman]]" by [[Hole (band)|Hole]], as well as tracks by artists such as [[White Zombie (band)|White Zombie]], [[Korn]], and [[Iggy Pop]]. Like the original ''Crow'' soundtrack, a song by [[Joy Division]] (one of O'Barr's favorite bands) is covered: "In a Lonely Place," by [[Bush (British band)|Bush]]. * ''[[The Crow: Salvation (soundtrack)|The Crow: Salvation]]'' (2000) — again compiled and produced by [[Jeff Most]]. As with the soundtrack to ''The Crow: City of Angels'', it includes an otherwise unavailable cover version by [[Hole (band)|Hole]]: this time of [[Bob Dylan]]'s "[[It's All Over Now, Baby Blue]]". Several other notable contemporary artists are also featured on the soundtrack. === Card games === The Crow is an out-of-print [[collectible card game]] by [[Heartbreaker Press]] and [[Target Games]]. It is based on The Crow [[comic]]s by [[James O'Barr]] and depicted images from the [[The Crow (movie)|movie]]. It was released in November 1995 but initially had a release date of March 1995.{{Citation |last=Miller |first=John Jackson |title=Scrye Collectible Card Game Checklist & Price Guide, Second Edition | year=2003 |page=109 |postscript=.}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cardboardconnection.com/upper-deck-lands-card-memorabilia-license-crow|title=The Crow Flies with Upper Deck in Trading Card and Memorabilia Deal|website=Carboardconnection.com|accessdate=2018-02-02}} It was one of three sets released by Heartbreaker Press and Target Games in November along with [[James Bond 007 Collectible Card Game|James Bond 007]] and [[Kult (card game)|Kult]]. The game did not have [[booster pack|starter decks]] and instead it had a core set with 122 cards that included 10 foils that had artwork from the comic.{{cite web|url=http://www.brandonlee.com/memorab/ccmas.htm|title=The Crow Card Game|website=Brandonlee.com|accessdate=2018-02-02}} The game was sold in [[booster pack]]s of 15 cards, but no starter packs were available.{{citation |last=Brown |first=Timothy|title=The Official Price Guide to Collectible Card Games|year=1999|pages=51-52|postscript=.}} A promo card called ''The Confident Crow'' was available by mail through proof-of-purchase order. An expansion titled ''Crow: City of Angels'' was announced for an October 1996 release but never materialized. Players control Angel, Devil, and Neutral Bystander cards and then send them into combat with "opposing [P]ersonalities". Action cards allow players to pump or hinder a Personality. Each Personality has an attack and defense value, as well as Virtue, which is equal to the highest value. Players play their card Personality card and discard cards from their hands equal to the Virtue of the played card, and then they attack. If a player has a higher attack value than their opponent's defense value, the opponent is wounded. If a Personality would be wounded again, it is killed. A player wins by killing 25 Virtue worth of an opponent's Personalities. == Bibliography == ===Comics=== *''The Crow'' (4 issues, 1989, [[Caliber Press]]) by [[James O'Barr]] ** Collected with the addition of new material as ''The Crow: Special Edition'' ([[Gallery Publishing Group|Gallery Books]], 2011) *''The Crow: Dead Time'' (3 issues, 1996, [[Kitchen Sink Press]]) story by James O'Barr & [[John Wagner]], art by [[Alexander Maleev]] ** Collected as ''The Crow: Midnight Legends'' Volume 1: ''Dead Time'' ([[IDW Publishing|IDW]]), 2012) *''The Crow: Flesh and Blood'' (3 issues, 1996, Kitchen Sink) story by [[James Vance (comics)|James Vance]], art by Alexander Maleev ** Collected as ''The Crow: Midnight Legends'' Volume 2: ''Flesh and Blood'' (IDW, 2012) *''The Crow: City of Angels'' (3 issues, 1996, Kitchen Sink) adapted from the screenplay)[https://www.mycomicshop.com/search?TID=123771 "Crow City of Angels (1996) comic books,"] MyComicShop.com. Accessed Dec. 28, 2017. *''The Crow: Wild Justice'' (3 issues, 1996, Kitchen Sink) story by [[Jerry Prosser]], art by [[Charlie Adlard]] ** Collected as ''The Crow: Midnight Legends'' Volume 3: ''Wild Justice'' (IDW, 2013) *''The Crow: Waking Nightmares'' (4 issues, 1997–1998, Kitchen Sink) story by [[Christopher Golden]], art by [[Phil Hester (comics)|Philip Hester]] ** Collected as ''The Crow: Midnight Legends'' Volume 4: ''Waking Nightmares'' (IDW, 2013) *''The Crow #0: A Cycle of Shattered Lives'' (one-shot, 1998, Kitchen Sink) story by James O'Barr / various *''The Crow / Razor: Kill the {{Infobox album | name = The Documentary 2.5 | type = Studio | artist = [[The Game (rapper)|The Game]] | cover = The-Documentary-2.5.jpg | alt = | released = {{Start date|2015|10|16|mf=y}} | recorded = 2013–15 | venue = | studio = Record Room Studios
{{small|([[Miami, Florida]])}}
Chalice Recording Studios
{{small|([[Hollywood, California]])}} | genre = {{flatlist| * [[West Coast hip hop]] * [[gangsta rap]] }} | length = 73:50 | label = {{flatlist| * [[The Game (rapper)#Blood Money Entertainment|Blood Money Entertainment]] * [[eOne Music]] }} | producer = {{flatlist| * The Game {{small|(also [[Executive producer#Music|exec]].)}} * [[Stat Quo]] {{small|(also exec.)}} * Cash "Wack100" Jones {{small|(co-exec.)}} * [[The Alchemist (musician)|The Alchemist]] * [[Mr. Bangladesh]] * [[Battlecat (producer)|Battlecat]] * Bongo * [[Cool & Dre]] * [[DJ Khalil]] * [[DJ Mustard]] * [[DJ Quik]] * [[Fredwreck]] * [[The Futuristiks|Mike & Keys]] * G Koop * [[Kevin Bivona]] * Nastradomas * [[Symbolyc One (S1)|S1]] * [[Skrillex]] * THX * [[Tone Mason]] * [[Travis Barker]] * [[will.i.am]] }} | prev_title = [[The Documentary 2]] | prev_year = 2015 | next_title = [[Streets of Compton]] | next_year = 2016 | misc = {{Singles | name = The Documentary 2.5 | type = Studio | single1 = [[El Chapo (song)|El Chapo]] | single1date = October 9, 2015 }} }} '''''The Documentary 2.5''''' is the seventh [[studio album]] by American [[Rapping|rapper]] [[The Game (rapper)|The Game]]. It was released on October 16, 2015, by [[The Game (rapper)#Blood Money Entertainment|Blood Money Entertainment]] and [[eOne Music]]. The album is the second half for the two-piece project that was divided from the first half of his sixth album ''[[The Documentary 2]]'' (2015), which was released a week earlier. The album features [[guest appearance]]s from [[will.i.am]], [[Schoolboy Q]], [[Jay Rock]], [[Nas]], [[DJ Quik]], [[Busta Rhymes]] and [[Problem (rapper)|Problem]], among others. The album was supported by the [[Single (music)|single]]: "[[El Chapo (song)|El Chapo]]" with [[Skrillex]]. ==Singles== The lead [[Single (music)|single]] from ''The Documentary 2.5'', "[[El Chapo (song)|El Chapo]]" was released on October 9, 2015. The song features a [[duet]] and additional vocals from [[disc jockey]] [[Skrillex]], who also [[Record production|produced]] this track, alongside [[Mr. Bangladesh]] and Nastradomas. ==Critical reception== {{Album ratings | MC = 79/100http://www.metacritic.com/music/the-documentary-25/the-game | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web|last1=Weiss|first1=Jeff|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-documentary-25-mw0002889111|title=The Documentary 2.5 Album Review|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=November 11, 2015}} | rev2 = ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' | rev2Score = {{Rating|4.5|5}}{{cite web|last1=Weiss|first1=Jeff|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/6730793/the-game-the-documentary-sequels-album-review|title=The Game Proves He's Still Relevant With 'The Documentary 2' and '2.5': Album Review|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} | rev3 = ''[[Now (newspaper)|NOW]]'' | rev3Score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web|last1=JUNEJA |first1=RAOUL |url=https://nowtoronto.com/music/album-reviews/the-game_1/|title=The Game - The Documentary 2/2.5|publisher=[[Now (newspaper)|NOW]]|accessdate=October 21, 2015}} | rev4 = RapReviews | rev4Score = 9/10{{cite web|last1=Soul|first1=Jay|url=http://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2015_10F_documentary2.html|title=The Game :: The Documentary 2 & Documentary 2.5|publisher=[[Rap Reviews]]|accessdate=October 20, 2015}} | rev5 = [[HipHopDX]] | rev5Score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web|last1=Bisnoff|first1=Jason|url=http://hiphopdx.com/reviews/id.2555/title.the-game-the-documentary-2-5|title=The Game - The Documentary 2.5 - Album Reviews | HipHopDX|publisher=[[HipHopDX]]|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} | rev6 = ''Zumic'' | rev6Score = {{Rating|4.5|5}}{{cite web|last1=Francois|first1=Sebastien |url=http://zumic.com/music-videos/207999/the-documentary-2-5-the-game-official-full-album-stream-zumic-review/|title="The Documentary 2.5" – The Game [Official Full Album Stream + Zumic Review]| publisher=Zumic|accessdate=November 3, 2015}} }} ''The Documentary 2.5'' received widespread reviews from contemporary [[music criticism|music critics]]. At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[standard score|normalized]] rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album received an [[weighted mean|average]] score of 79, which indicates "generally favorable reviews", based on 6 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/the-documentary-25/the-game |title=Reviews for The Documentary 2.5 by The Game - Metacritic |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=December 13, 2015}} ==Commercial performance== ''The Documentary 2.5'' debuted at number six on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] with 48,000 [[album-equivalent unit]]s, which included 42,000 pure album sales.{{Cite news|first=Keith|last=Caulfield|title=Pentatonix Scores First No. 1 Album on Billboard 200 Chart|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6738540/pentatonix-first-no-1-album-billboard-200-chart|work=Billboard|date=2015-10-26|accessdate=2015-10-26}} It serves as The Game's eighth top-ten album in the United States. The album dropped to the number 29 in its second week, earning an additional 15,000 album-equivalent units. As of November 2015, ''The Documentary 2.5'' had accumulated 63,000 album-equivalent units in the United States, with 54,000 being pure sales.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/charts-dont-lie-november-4-news.18532.html|title=Charts Don't Lie: November 4, 2015|publisher=hotnewhiphop.com|author=Trevor Smith|date=November 4,
